author: LeocantoKosta_
body: NVDA is great, seems a little expensive though. Long term probably doesn't matter. I would avoid Intel. I like the trio of semi equipment companies - ASML, LRCX, AMAT. I also like some of the fabless chipmakers like AVGO, TXN, and NXP. TSMC might be good as well. Ultimately, you could spread out across some names, or maybe a semiconductor ETF like SOXX or PSI.

author: DoggyFrench
body: Knowing this boomer administration it’s probably going towards companies with 0 Taiwan foundation or aesthetic. So essentially, Intel, AMAT, Texas Instruments, Qualcomm, and NXP.

author: CareerLow
body:
Ok, ready to start sharing some more of the data set I built for Russell Reconstitution Trade Theories. Looking for feedback before some of this goes out in the YEET tonight. Will make separate comment for each theory with explanation behind it. 

Starting with Large Caps, but can post Small Cap follow up if mods and everyone cool with it?

One rule applies to all theories- Stocks are weighted by FAMC (Float Adj. MC) which is hard to find so did rough estimate myself. More confident in my math after I saw Goldman had similar top 10. Not precise, but should be relatively close. 

Large Cap Buying Pressure: Stocks being added to Russell 1K for the first time will experience more buying pressure if they are weighted near the top. (Jeffries report in parenthesis)  
  
BX- RK1 (#2 in Buying Pressure by $)  
SNOW- RK1 (#1 in Buying Pressure by $)  
NXPI- RK1 (#4 in Buying Pressure by $)  
DASH- RK1 (#5 in Buying Pressure by $) - can't wait to short this fucker post rebalance, next ER feels right for redemption  
PLTR- RK1 (#3 in Buying Pressure by $)  
DKNG- RK1 (#6 in Buying Pressure by $)  
WIX- RK1 (#8 in Buying Pressure by $)

author: YeMothor2457
body:
Hello all,

I'm new to investing and this is my planned portfolio:

NXP Semiconductors (NXPI): 9.70%  
Apple (AAPL): 13.01%  
Coca-Cola (KO): 8.51%  
American Express (AXP): 4.01%  
DaVita (DVA): 4.59%  
Johnson & Johnson (JNJ): 7.08%  
Microsoft (MSFT): 5.22%  
PayPal (PYPL): 5.34%  
Vanguard FTSE All-World (VWRL): 10.52%  
Corsair Gaming (CRSR): 5.13%  
Vestas (VWSB): 4.94%  
Cresco (6CQ): 3.65%  
Visa (V): 5.93%  
iShares Core S&P 500 (ISSP): 4.47%  
Invesco EQQQ NASDAQ-100 (QQQ): 4.29%  
Qualcomm (QCOM): 1.40%

This portfolio is meant for holding, about 5-10 years.  
Tips, advice and opinions are very welcome!

author: Incendras
body: Semi bill passed. Semi time, INTC/NXPI are going to print.

author: TheMadBeaker
body:
The global markets can't get enough chips right now. Lead times are crazy, and most fabs are \*just\* starting to raise prices, which we should see some really great Q2/Q3 profits. Many have committed billions to more fabs, but those will be years before they come online.

There is never going to be a decline in chip demand, they keep shoving more and more in everything.

Some stocks I bought early March: I'm up over 40% on NVDA, 23% on AMAT, 17% on NXPI, and 17% on UMC, 13% on TXN.

**\*Not stock advice\***

author: YeMothor2457
body:
Thanks!

Why would you remove VWRL over ISSP and NXPI to QQQ?  
My main reason for NXPI is because I did my internship there and have some trust for the future.

author: SirGasleak
body: Have a look at NXPI, a top holding in some of the EV ETFs.

author: fenwickfox
body:
Still undecided on it. Yes, it's a concentrated play on semis, but theres probably another ETF that gets most of these for less than .45%.

I think the big fish are nvda, amd, tsm nxp and intc.

author: SirGasleak
body: NXPI is a good under the radar choice, it's a top holding in some of the EV ETFs.

author: Mr_Prestonius
body: Surprised I haven’t seen NXPI mentioned here more. They’re obviously smaller, but as one of the only other companies actually manufacturing I think there’s a lot of room for growth on this one.

author: Kva1234
body:
I'm from El Salvador, and this could be nothing but a lie. Yes, a lot of people receive remittances, but transmitting dollars doesn't cost 50% in fees. If you're sending money from the US to here, you barely pay normal western Union fees, which are like $8 for every $100. People over here are not educated enough to know the risks this move implies for our population. 

Currently, this idiot cut ties with OAS and is looking to cut ties with the US and have China as our main economic partner, just as Nicaragua did (take a look at their economy and see how they're doing). This is a disaster, uneducated population taking on high risk speculation, while cutting ties with the country that supplies 80% of our oil, for one that enslaves its people.

This move will basically make El Salvador safe haven for the corrupt ones in the world because it wouldn't be possible to trace their stolen money to have them accountable for something. By cutting ties with OAS, we're becoming a no-extradition country. The worst part is, ignorant people who voted for him still supports this crap even after being explained to.

You live by the jumper, you die by the jumper, kids. If you live by the meme, you will die by it too. Develop a post up game, do some research. Like Wu-Tang once said, diversify your bonds.

author: nomindbody
body:
I'm holding off a bit until more under $10. They're stacked with debt, but all other metrics look good. However, their lead tech person left and the "tech" they were touting for gaining consumer insights at the last shareholder meeting was a wordcloud (super basic).

To give some perspective on value, $WU is $20ish and $BABA was going to pay $18 a share for MGI awhile ago before it was blocked.

So I'm targeting an entry close to $6-7 or lower, but play the news as it's going to be a long road for them.

author: AcanthocephalaOk1042
body:
The lawsuits are just typical stock drop nonsense that comes with a short report.  The firm's that filed them literally do this to any company that has a short report.  

I agree the earnings report audit issue is certainly a cause to pause.  However with their activities with securing partnerships ( western union ) and their acquisitions balance that out to me.  

As I said in the title, moderate risk, not a sure thing.  At it's current price I'd still say it's a buy.  If it's 8 or above I'd say hold for that information to come out.

With the current buying frenzies in heavily shorted stocks, and this is certainly shorted to the max, it could easily spike much higher and provide nice gains for those who get in at the current prices

author: vladedivac12
body:
So much hate on this sub for crypto. Are you guys invested in Western Union or what?

70% of people in El Salvador have no bank accounts. 
 In 2020 $5.9 billion, or roughly approximately 23% of the country's total economic output came from remittances. Instead of paying huge fees to overseas intermediaries, why not keep the % fee in the economy?

It's not like previous regimes or the international community (Imf) has done anything to help El Salvador in the past decades. This guy is trying something new and different to help them get out of povrety.
